messages.text: Is there a way to delete a contiguous range of columns from the end of a matrix in Julia?  I'm implementing a function which returns the column equivalence classes for a matrix and (ideally) modifies it in-place to only contain its unique columns. I can efficiently move the unique columns to the start of the array, but I can't find a way to change the array's size without allocating a new array. Is this possible, given that the block of memory I want to free is contiguous and at the end of the block allocated for the initial matrix?

text.text:
Is there a way to delete a contiguous range of columns from the end of a matrix in Julia?

I'm implementing a function which returns the column equivalence classes for a matrix and (ideally) modifies it in-place to only contain its unique columns. I can efficiently move the unique columns to the start of the array, but I can't find a way to change the array's size without allocating a new array. Is this possible, given that the block of memory I want to free is contiguous and at the end of the block allocated for the initial matrix?

messages.text: hello juliers, i have a noob question. in python i can use numpy to quickly read a file and assign its columns to array very quickly using something like data = np.genfromtxt('file_name', unpack=True, skip_header=1).   then data[0] is an array containing the first column of file_name.    what would be a nice equivalent way to do that in julia?

text.text: hello juliers, i have a noob question. in python i can use numpy to quickly read a file and assign its columns to array very quickly using something like data = np.genfromtxt('file_name', unpack=True, skip_header=1).   then data[0] is an array containing the first column of file_name.    what would be a nice equivalent way to do that in julia?

messages.text: In general, running julia scripts from the command line means that you're restarting julia totally from scratch every time.

text.text: In general, running julia scripts from the command line means that you're restarting julia totally from scratch every time.

messages.text: for interactive use you're "meant to" leave a Julia repl open and just use that; for non-interactive use you'll have to use PackageCompiler.jl or something like that

text.text: for interactive use you're "meant to" leave a Julia repl open and just use that; for non-interactive use you'll have to use PackageCompiler.jl or something like that

messages.text: ah,  so I should use it in a jupyter notebook then i guess

text.text: ah,  so I should use it in a jupyter notebook then i guess

messages.text: So the more common workflow is to have an editor with  repl open and then just `include()` your scripts from the repl

text.text: So the more common workflow is to have an editor with  repl open and then just `include()` your scripts from the repl

messages.text: If you want to run scripts anyways, then putting your most-used packages in a system image with PackageCompiler.jl would probably be good

text.text: If you want to run scripts anyways, then putting your most-used packages in a system image with PackageCompiler.jl would probably be good

messages.text: Welcome and go ahead!
essentially I do a monte carlo calculation.  I have a set of calculations that I perform over and over, in a loop.   in each of these single calculations, I pick some variables in a random way.

text.text: essentially I do a monte carlo calculation.  I have a set of calculations that I perform over and over, in a loop.   in each of these single calculations, I pick some variables in a random way.

messages.text: I notice, in julia, that maybe I could possibly avoid the loop, and instead of running each calculation on its own (up to its output), I could use vectors instead.  for example if I do L = Normal(5e-3, 1e-4), L will be picked randomly around 5e-3, with python I continue the calculations with that value, up to the end.  and i repeat this, in a loop .  but in julia I could do L_vector = rand(L, 100).

text.text: I notice, in julia, that maybe I could possibly avoid the loop, and instead of running each calculation on its own (up to its output), I could use vectors instead.  for example if I do L = Normal(5e-3, 1e-4), L will be picked randomly around 5e-3, with python I continue the calculations with that value, up to the end.  and i repeat this, in a loop .  but in julia I could do L_vector = rand(L, 100).

messages.text: in which case L_vector will be an array (or something like that), with 100 different values of L, picked around 5e-3.    I could do the same thing for all variables, and perform a single calculation on all the obtained arrays

text.text: in which case L_vector will be an array (or something like that), with 100 different values of L, picked around 5e-3.    I could do the same thing for all variables, and perform a single calculation on all the obtained arrays

messages.text: You can do vector calculation in Julia, like in Python, but in Julia, loops are just as fast

elements.text: You can do vector calculation in Julia, like in Python, but in Julia, loops are just as fast

messages.text: `readdlm("filename")`  by default will read whitespace-delimited

text.text: `readdlm("filename")`  by default will read whitespace-delimited

messages.text: ``` help?> readdlm search: readdlm readdir    readdlm(source, T::Type; options...)    The columns are assumed to be separated by one or more whitespaces. The end of line   delimiter is taken as \n.    Examples   ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡    julia> using DelimitedFiles    julia> x = [1; 2; 3; 4];    julia> y = [5; 6; 7; 8];    julia> open("delim_file.txt", "w") do io              writedlm(io, [x y])          end;    julia> readdlm("delim_file.txt", Int64)   4×2 Array{Int64,2}:    1  5    2  6    3  7    4  8    julia> readdlm("delim_file.txt", Float64)   4×2 Array{Float64,2}:    1.0  5.0    2.0  6.0    3.0  7.0    4.0  8.0    julia> rm("delim_file.txt") ```

text.text:
```
help?> readdlm
search: readdlm readdir

  readdlm(source, T::Type; options...)

  The columns are assumed to be separated by one or more whitespaces. The end of line
  delimiter is taken as \n.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> using DelimitedFiles

  julia> x = [1; 2; 3; 4];

  julia> y = [5; 6; 7; 8];

  julia> open("delim_file.txt", "w") do io
             writedlm(io, [x y])
         end;

  julia> readdlm("delim_file.txt", Int64)
  4×2 Array{Int64,2}:
   1  5
   2  6
   3  7
   4  8

  julia> readdlm("delim_file.txt", Float64)
  4×2 Array{Float64,2}:
   1.0  5.0
   2.0  6.0
   3.0  7.0
   4.0  8.0

  julia> rm("delim_file.txt")
```
